The answer to this question seems to be very hard to define. Maybe it should just be cancelled. What counts as a "cyber attack"? What is "a nuclear facility"? I assume that malware that turned off a nuclear power station, or disrupted an uranium enrichment facility would count. But a laptop used by a student in a warehouse that stored nuclear medical material that got a virus that stole an Amazon password would not.  There must be thousands of places that use or research some kind of nuclear material, that could be called "nuclear facilities", but most of us would not call it that. A "cyber attack" sounds as if it means it was specifically targeted, but most malware is targeted at something. A "targeted attack" could be targeted at users of specific hardware, or software which could be specific to one facility or it could be targeted at duel use hardware or software. If attacks that took place before the question was set and those disclosed after it ends may or may not be excluded we end up with the answer being very fuzzy. I don't think we can forecast events where there is no clarity as whether they count or not.

Swift Banking Network Struggles With Wave of Cyberattacks
Gaps in security standards and poor communication about breaches have exposed vulnerabilities of the global money-transfer network
Banks rely on the network, formally called the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication, to guarantee the authenticity of orders to make payments from customers’ accounts. Hacking incidents at banks in Bangladesh, Vietnam and Ecuador have called that guarantee into question.
In each case, the attackers were able to obtain the banks’ Swift access codes and send authenticated but fraudulent requests to transfer funds. Swift wasn’t aware of the incidents in Vietnam or Ecuador until well after the attacks had taken place. Thieves stole $81 million from Bangladesh’s central bank in February and about $9 million from a lender in Ecuador last year.
More such incidents could emerge. Swift said in a note said it knew of recent fraud at a “small number” of customers. Cybersecurity firm FireEye Inc. said the thieves behind the Bangladesh attack appear to still be active.

Clearly there already have been cases of cyber attacks on nuclear facilities (e.g. stuxnet) and people have been accused of planning all sorts of attacks on nuclear facilities. So the nub of the question is "publicly disclosed". The "public disclosure" could came from a perpetrator or a target. Unless the perpetrator had been successful enough to have caused undeniable harm their would seem to be little to gain for the perpetrator to "publicly disclose" the attack. Even if successful, state agencies would seem to to have more to lose than gain by "public disclosing" a successful cyber attack on a nuclear facility. It seems even less likely that the target would want to alarm the public by admitting a successful cyber attack. It more likely that a success that causes undeniable harm would be blamed on something other than a cyber attack.

I'm going to dig into this more, but its tricky - the public disclosure versus the actual attack itself. Nitro Zeus wasn't launched, - but was disclosed, which makes me question it since its now featured in a documentary, and feels like a cautionary tale more than a post-event analysis - like the Stuxnet attack.
Here's my 'straw man plan':
- Number of nuclear facilities operational by country, with MWe Net
- Existing conflicts between top nation-states with the greatest # of operable facilities and MWe.
- Type of cyber attack - Zero Day/SCADA vulnerability - how these are introduced into the facilities & the time it takes to execute: example: Stuxnet took years to develop, but now the blueprint for it exists in the open.
- Development of cyber defense post Stuxnet that would counter these attacks
- How are attacks reported out publicly - by what means?
My assumption is that an attack capable of dismantling a nuclear facility would take time to develop, then would take time to implement post-Stuxnet, and the subsequent publicly acknowledged disclosure of this would be contested and guarded against so I'm initially predicting a low probability for before the end of 2016.  After 2016 and around other power/water plants that have more open SCADA vulnerabilities, and could be attacked by a smaller effort is more concerning.

Low probability and even lower probability that it is acknowledged.

1) The recent case of stuxnet attack on Iranian nuclear facilities suggests that cyber attacks on nuclear facilities require high level of technical sophistication and organizational capacity. This suggests that only a small number of actors--namely some states like the United States, Russia, China, Israel, and North Korea may be able to do that. 
2) There has been no publicly disclosed attempts by these countries to attack other states' nuclear facilities other than the stuxnet case. And they seem to have no strong incentives to do that before the end of 2016.  
3) Even if some nuke facilities got attacked, victim countries are likely to hide the info to prevent public panic and/or outrage. 
4) These factors lead me to 5% chance, but I add 5% considering the development and spread of hacking technology since the stuxnet case and the development of SNS.

I believe this a question is vague and that "cyber attacks" occur on a daily basis.  As a grad student in Cyber Security I'm not impressed by the catchall term when Stuxnet is certainly a perturbation from something benign like a software update malfunction. Vulnerability cuts both ways and can be self-inflicted as much as externally attacked.  I interpret this question as to leave open a benign mistake such as happened in the U.S. state of Georgia (2008).  That's fundamentally different than an external malicious attack.  Two publicized cyber attacks were internal accidents from updates that triggered safety procedures leading to shutdowns.  Hearsay about unauthorized internet connections and potential SCAD entry points are very unlikely to be found, exploited, NOTICED, and reported within a year given that Nuclear facilities FEAR of this known threat and thus UNWILLINGNESS to publicize a breach that is consequential to security because it's kinda alarmist.

-> US follow-up attack on Iran 6%
-> Non-US demonstration 15%
-> Accidental disclosure 0%
-> Disclosure of unsuccessful attack 3%

I'm less interested in whether there will be cyber attacks, and am more concerned with whether those attacks will be publicly disclosed. Stuxnet and its target the Iranian Nuclear Weapons Program were only discovered/disclosed because the worm spread so voraciously. That kind of spreading is either a desperation-driven mistake (unlikely) or a subtle demonstration of capability and intent to those who might interfere with the interests of the attackers. (Source: Countdown to Zero Day).

There will almost certainly be an attack given how many attacks take place daily. So it's really a question of whether it gets reported or not. If hackers are successful it will definitely become disclosed, even if not someone is likely to cite attacks as a reason for more funding. All of the equipment in question is specially designed middleware that is not susceptible to outside attack without specific and intimate systems knowledge.  This leaves either former employees or foreign governments with civilian nuclear energy programs that use the same technology as possible attackers.
  In the case of a former employee attack, public disclosure is not likely.  A former employee, no matter how disgruntled, would not cause a meltdown to endanger thousands of lives in the form that would be immediately apparent to the public.  The basic physiological screening required of employees in nuclear plants does prevent the hiring of someone so inclined to mass destruction.  In the case of a smaller scale event, such as threatening the lives of employees in specific areas of the plant, it would not be publicly disclosed.
  There are many foreign governments with nuclear programs that work with major civilian nuclear energy systems, such as Turkey.   An attack would undermine public trust in civilian nuclear energy.  Knowing that an attack would undermine civilian nuclear energy a lifelong scholar that is working in a civilian nuclear energy program would be unwilling to participate in that attack.   While participation could be coerced, the complexity of a remote attack would make it impossible for one person or a small group to pull off under duress.   I think an attack by a government currently cooperating in civilian nuclear energy programs will not happen in 2016.
  The last possible is someone without knowledge in civilian nuclear systems attacking a system remotely.  This is very possible, but it is not possible that anyone achieve an ends without understanding the systems involved. If an attack of this unprepared kind were to happen there would be no result and it would not be disclosed publicly.
  I think it is not probable at all that there is a real attack on nuclear facilities disclosed to the public.  I think there is a chance that a public announcement is made about a perceived threat, potential attack, or imagined attack for political purposes but that this event and announcement will have no supporting evidence of an actual attack, attacker, motive, or specific target.

Cyber attacks on critical infrastructure are routine, near daily events, so it is likely there have already been cyber attacks on nuclear facilities.  The issue, however, is whether the authorities (DHS, NRC, DOE, utility officials, local and federal law enforcement) would publicly disclose that an attack, even a failed attack, had occurred.  There would be nothing to be gained for the authorities from publicly disclosing that a failed attack had occurred.  If, however, a cyber attack succeeded in some fashion, then public disclosure would be more likely since disclosure would contribute to answering the public's questions about why there was some sort of failure or irregularity at the nuke plant in the first place.  Since it is unlikely that there will be a successful cyber attack on a nuclear facility then it is relatively unlikely that any cyber attack would be disclosed.
